nodes.name: Sticky Note

parameters.content:
## Setting Up Medoids for Anomaly Detection
### Preparatory workflow to set cluster centres and cluster threshold scores, so anomalies can be detected based on these thresholds
Here, we're using two approaches to set up these centres: the upper branch is the *"distance matrix approach"*, and the lower is the *"multimodal embedding model approach"*.

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note1

parameters.content: Once again, variables for Qdrant: cluster URL and a collection we're working with

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note2

parameters.content: Which point in the cluster we're using to draw threshold on: the furthest one from center, or the 2nd, ... Xth furthest one;

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note3

parameters.content: Here we are getting [facet counts]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} information which unique values are there behind *"crop_name"* payload and how many points have these values (for example, we have 31 *"cucumber"* and 29 *"cotton"*)

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note4

parameters.content:
Which point in the cluster we're using to draw threshold on: the furthest one from center, or the 2nd, ... Xth furthest one;
<this is the 2nd approach>

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note5

parameters.content:
We need to get the [total amount of points]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} in Qdrant collection to use it as a `limit` in the *"Crop Counts"* node, so we won't lose any information;
<not the best practice per se>

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note6

parameters.content:
Here we're extracting and gathering all the information about crop clusters, so we can call [Qdrant distance matrix API]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} for each cluster.
We're propagating **the biggest cluster size** (of labeled data, in our case all data is labeled; for real use cases don't call distance matrix API if your labeled data is more than a couple of hundreds), **the number of unique crop values** and **unique crop values** themselves. We will run the algorithm once per unique crop cluster (to find it's center and threshold).

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note8

parameters.content: Hardcoded descriptions on how each crop usually looks; They were generated with chatGPT, and that can be technically done directly in n8n based on the crop name or a crop picture (we need a good description of how the most normal specimen of a crop looks like)

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note9
nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Split Out
nodes.notes: This splitOut node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note10

parameters.content: Splitting out into each unique crop cluster

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note11

parameters.content: Using distance matrix generated by Qdrant and `coo_array` from `scipy`, we're finding a **representative** for each cluster (point which is the most similar to all other points within a cluster, based on the **Cosine** distance)

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note12

parameters.content:
To find a **representative** with this approach, we:
1) Embed descriptions of crops with the same Voyage model we used for images (we can do so, since model is multimodal)
2) For each (crop) cluster, find an image the closest by **Cosine** similarity metric to this embedded description. We will consider it a perfect representative of the cluster

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note13

parameters.content:
Embedding descriptions with Voyage model 
[Note] mind `input_type`, it's *"query"*

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note14

parameters.content:
Find the closest image to the description embeddings (done per cluster)
[Note] Mind `exact` parameter
[Note] `limit` is 1 because vector database always returns points sorted by distance from the most similar one to the least
[Note] `using` parameter is here  because our vectors uploaded in the previous pipeline are named *"voyage"*.

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Set text medoid threshold score
nodes.notes: This httpRequest node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note15

parameters.content: Fetching vectors of centres by their IDs

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note16

parameters.content: Set in Qdrant *"is_medoid"* [payloads]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} for points which were defined as centres by *"distance matrix approach"*

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note17

parameters.content: Here, we don't have to fetch a vector by point id as in the *"distance matrix approach"*, since [an API call in the previous node]({{ $env.API_BASE_URL }} is able to return vectors stored in Qdrant as a response, while the distance matrix API returns only points IDs.

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note18

parameters.content: Set in Qdrant *"is_text_anchor_medoid"* [payloads]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} for points which were defined as centres by *"multimodal embedding model approach"*.

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note19

parameters.content: Starting from here, this and the three following nodes are analogous for both methods, with a difference only in variable names. The goal is to find a **class (cluster) threshold score** so we can use it for anomaly detection (for each class).

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note20

parameters.content: Finding the most dissimilar point to a centre vector (within each class) is equivalent to finding the most similar point to the [opposite]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} of a centre vector, aka the centre vector with all coordinates multiplied by -1. It is always true with **Cosine** vector similarity metric (that we're using).

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note21

parameters.content: So here, we found the most dissimilar point within the crop class to the class centre (or the Xth dissimilar point, depending on a variable set in the beginning of this pipeline). Our **threshold score** is the similarity score between this point and the class centre. Now we're saving it as meta information of each class centre point. All preparatory work for anomaly detection is done.

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

nodes.name: Sticky Note22

parameters.content:
### For anomaly detection
1. The first pipeline is uploading (crops) dataset to Qdrant's collection.
2. **This is the second pipeline, to set up cluster (class) centres in this Qdrant collection & cluster (class) threshold scores.**
3. The third one is the anomaly detection tool, which takes any image as input and uses all preparatory work done with Qdrant (crops) collection.

### To recreate it
You'll have to upload [crops]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} dataset from Kaggle to your own Google Storage bucket, and re-create APIs/connections to [Qdrant Cloud]({{ $env.WEBHOOK_URL }} (you can use **Free Tier** cluster), Voyage AI API & Google Cloud Storage

**In general, pipelines are adaptable to any dataset of images**

nodes.notes: This stickyNote node performs automated tasks as part of the workflow.

parameters.content:
# [2/3] Set up medoids (2 types) for anomaly detection (crops dataset)

## Overview
Automated workflow: [2/3] Set up medoids (2 types) for anomaly detection (crops dataset). This workflow integrates 8 different services: stickyNote, httpRequest, code, splitOut, merge. It contains 72 nodes and follows best practices for error handling and security.

## Workflow Details
- **Total Nodes**: 72
- **Node Types**: 8
- **Error Handling**: ✅ Implemented
- **Security**: ✅ Hardened (no sensitive data)
- **Documentation**: ✅ Complete

## Node Breakdown
- **When clicking ‘Test workflow’**: manualTrigger
- **Total Points in Collection**: httpRequest
- **Cluster Distance Matrix**: httpRequest
- **Scipy Sparse Matrix**: code
- **Set medoid id**: httpRequest
- **Get Medoid Vector**: httpRequest
- **Prepare for Searching Threshold**: set
- **Searching Score**: httpRequest
- **Threshold Score**: set
- **Set medoid threshold score**: httpRequest
- ... and 62 more nodes

## Usage Instructions
1. **Configure Credentials**: Set up all required API keys and credentials
2. **Update Variables**: Replace any placeholder values with actual data
3. **Test Workflow**: Run in test mode to verify functionality
4. **Deploy**: Activate the workflow for production use

## Security Notes
- All sensitive data has been removed or replaced with placeholders
- Error handling is implemented for reliability
- Follow security best practices when configuring credentials

## Troubleshooting
- Check error logs if workflow fails
- Verify all credentials are properly configured
- Ensure all required services are accessible

# [2/3] Set up medoids (2 types) for anomaly detection (crops dataset)

## Overview
Automated workflow: [2/3] Set up medoids (2 types) for anomaly detection (crops dataset). This workflow integrates 8 different services: stickyNote, httpRequest, code, splitOut, merge. It contains 72 nodes and follows best practices for error handling and security.
